awd_titl_txt: Development of Novel Augmented Reality Tool for Teaching Molecular Visualization in Biochemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
A core learning objective for students in biochemistry courses is understanding the relationship between the function and the structure of macromolecules, such as proteins.  However, instructors must typically teach students about 3D molecules by using 2D images. As a result, many students have trouble grasping key elements of 3D macromolecular structure, including scale and the effects of molecular shape changes.  This project aims to address this limitation by developing an augmented reality (AR) application to visualize 3D macromolecules that are central to understanding biochemistry, cell biology, molecular biology, and genetics. AR is an interactive system in which a computer-generated 3D object is superimposed onto the physical environment. This project aims to develop a freely available AR-based application that can be installed on mobile smartphones and tablets and that can be used to visualize and manipulate macromolecules. The project seeks to implement the application in classes at two liberal arts colleges that include a combined total of ~100 students each year. It will also assess the impact of these AR-based teaching tools on student learning. Since the AR application will be freely available, it can enable the public to easily 'see' and interact with biological macromolecules that are important to human health. 

To address the current gap in instructional tools available for teaching macromolecular structure, this project has three objectives: 1) Develop an application that uses AR technology to allow students and instructors to engage and interact with virtual 3D macromolecular structures; 2) Develop three learning modules on biochemistry topics of membrane transport (potassium channel), allosteric regulation (hemoglobin), active site catalysis (G-proteins); 3) Implement each learning module and evaluate its impacts in biochemistry courses taught by different instructors at different institutions. The project will evaluate the impacts of AR technology on both student learning outcomes and on potential changes to instructional practices in the classroom. The project aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the modules with respect to i) user experience with the technology; ii) impacts on student attitudes and visuospatial skills; and iii) impacts on instructional practices of using virtual 3D objects to teach macromolecular structure and function. During evaluation, the project will also develop and validate new instruments for effective assessment of the modules. The project aims to disseminate the AR applications through workshops for interested instructors and professional science educators, thus layin the groundwork for academic collaborations and community partnerships that can develop additional interactive AR modules. In addition to providing a novel tool for teaching molecular structure and function, the project will lay a strong foundational framework for the evaluation and development of additional AR-based teaching tools in the future.  This project is supported by NSF's Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) Program:  Engaged Student Learning (Exploration and Design tier).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nearly all biological processes rely on protein molecules to execute each step necessary for a successful biological outcome. The function of these protein molecules (how they play their specific role in the process) is inherently reliant on the shape of these molecules. Just as a key with a particular shape is specific to a certain lock, protein shapes are specific to certain functions. The ability to visualize the shape of the key in 3-dimensions (3D) is crucial to understanding how it unlocks its lock; similarly, the ability to visualize the shape of a protein in 3D is crucial to understanding its function (the shape of antibodies that can specifically recognize and target Covid-19 spike proteins is a recent example). In biochemistry education, classroom activities that allow students to manipulate (rotate, translate, zoom) 3D virtual models of biological macromolecules (such as proteins) in a digital environment have been shown to improve student visuospatial skills as well as student understanding of how macromolecular structure relates to function. However, these interventions vary widely with regards to usability of the required software/hardware components as well as the investment (both financial and time) required by the instructor and/or institution to effectively implement these activities in a classroom setting. Augmented Reality (AR) technology is a low-cost, easy to use digital platform for the manipulation of virtual 3D objects, including 3D models of biological macromolecules. In AR, a video display shows an overlay of a virtual 3D object projected over the real world. Current instructional resources available for the use of AR in teaching protein biochemistry are sharply limited to only a few custom software suites that require the use of significant hardware (cameras, desktop computers, and monitors) and are not intuitive to use.

This project aimed to increase the accessibility of this technology for teaching macromolecular structures to novice users (both instructors and students) by developing a novel AR-based software application called BiochemAR to allow students and instructors to easily engage with and interact with virtual 3D macromolecular structures. We developed three learning modules focused on central biochemistry topics/molecules intended to suit a broad range of biochemistry curriculums: membrane transport (potassium channel), allosteric regulation (hemoglobin), and active site catalysis (G-proteins). Each module contained a virtual 3D model that would be displayed using AR as well as instructional materials for incorporation into the classroom. We piloted each module multiple times in a biochemistry classroom in order to refine the software/learning materials before broader dissemination into the community. In addition to developing the software and learning materials, this project also directly assessed the impact of AR technology on student conceptions of biochemistry concepts and group dynamics in the classroom. We found that student attitudes towards visiospatial reasoning and confidence in structure-function relationships increase after interacting with models of the potassium channel (Sung RJ, et al. JCE 2019). We found that students use a wide range of gestures to communicate their conception of biochemical concepts, and that these gesture patterns shift following exposure to the virtual 3D model (Randa L, et al. CBE-LSE 2024). Lastly, we show that deployment of this technology in the classroom can exacerbate or continue inequities in group dynamics without additional structure or guidance from the instructor, a particularly important finding as classroom technologies continue to proliferate (Wang S, et al. JRST 2023). Altogether, this work has broadened access and awareness of AR technology as a teaching tool for biochemistry, as well as provided new frameworks for the effective use of AR technology in classrooms.
